description.narrative: The objective of this contribution is to provide life-saving assistance to people affected by food insecurity and malnutrition through support to WFP's humanitarian operations in a number of countries, annually identified by Sida's humanitarian Unit during the course of the allocation process or as a response to sudden changes in the humanitarian situation in-country. The contribution from Sida will mainly be used for (i) food assistance, (ii) targeted nutrition interventions and (iii) transport and logistics on behalf of the whole humanitarian community.

Insatsen avser humanitärt stöd genom World Food Program (WFP) för perioden 2019-2021. WFP har varit en regelbunden partner för genomförandet av Sidas humanitära insatser senast genom ett flerårigt avtal för perioden 2015-2017, samt ett avtal för 2018. Det föreslås nu att återigen ingå ett treårigt avtal för att öka förutsägbarhet och flexibilitet i samarbetet. Av 2019 års stöd från Sida, totalt 151 MSEK, avses 96 MSEK att användas för WFP:s huvudverksamhet varav 90 MSEK till akuta matsäkerhetsinsatser och 6 MSEK till kapacitetsstöd. Resterande 55 MSEK avses användas till finansiering av United Nations Humanitarian Air Services (UNHAS) för att förbättra tillträde till människor i behov av humanitär hjälp.

This contribution entails humanitarian support through the World Food Program (WFP) for the period 2019-2021. WFP has been a regular partner for the implementation of Sida's humanitarian assistance through a multi-year agreement for the period 2015-2017, and an agreement for 2018. It is hereby proposed to enter into a new three-year agreement to increase predictability and flexibility of the cooperation. Of 2019 years' support from Sida, amounting to a total of 151 million SEK, 96 million SEK will be distributed for WFP's core activities, including 90 MSEK for emergency food security interventions and 6 MSEK for capacity strengthening, while the remaining SEK 55 million will be used to finance the United Nations Humanitarian Air Services (UNHAS) to improve access to people in need of humanitarian aid.

tag.narrative: 2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

description.narrative:
Sida's humanitarian support to WFP in 2019-2021 amounted to approximately 1.2 billion SEK (2019; 329 MSEK, 2020; 366 MSEK and 2021; 519 MSEK) covering 22 countries and a thematic support develop WFP's protection strategy. Around 80 percent of the funds were for food security interventions and resilience in the countries, while UNHAS received the rest of the funds.
WFP was able to achieve significant results despite funding shortages. According to the 2020 Annual Performance Report, WFP and its partners provided direct assistance to some 115.5 million beneficiaries of whom 61.6 million were women and girls and 53.9 million were men and boys. WFP distributed 4.2 million metric tons of food and USD 2.1 billion in cash-based transfers (CBTs), and reached 11 percent more beneficiaries through food assistance and 37 percent more through CBTs than in 2019. The increase in the number of beneficiaries was not matched by an increase in the total amount of food or CBT distributed in 2020 compared with 2019, because of a variety of reasons: reduction in ration sizes in some countries related to insufficient funding; problems with access or pipeline breaks; changes in modalities from food to CBT as COVID-19-related restrictions made it more difficult to distribute in-kind food; and the impact of fluctuations in exchange rates. WFP also provided common services such as UNHAS which enabled access to many hard-to-reach areas as well as countries which lack infrastructure because of poverty. UNHAS enabled 248,026 passengers transported, 3,975 Mt cargo transported, 409 medical evacuations completed, 32 COVID-19 medical evacuations and 932 security relocations.
WFP was named the Nobel Peace Prize Laureate in 2020, with the motivation: "for its efforts to combat hunger, for its contribution to bettering conditions for peace in conflict-affected areas and for acting as a driving force in efforts to prevent the use of hunger as a weapon of war and conflict." The Prize gave due recognition of the inexorable link between peace and food security, and provided an energizing boost to WFP's employees as they stayed and delivered in frequently shifting field of operations affected by COVID-19, conflict and climate change. The naming of WFP as Nobel Peace Prize Laureate has led to a redoubling of its efforts to continue providing principled and high-quality assistance to affected communities and their governments. It is however too early to say whether WFP's fund-raising has benefited from the Prize.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
